Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 01:54PM anji111 wrote: Hi everyone.  I just received my path report this week.  It said "One of 19 Lymph Nodes Positive for Metastasis, 1.2cm."  I am apparently 'only' Stage II.  Why should this be any different than Stage IV distant mets?  As far as I am concerned "metastasis is metastasis" period!  Meaning it has spread.  Which is not good at whatever stage you are or where ever it has spread to.  I wish you all had something better to do with your time.  "Right" fighting doesn't get us anywhere.  I do not feel encouraged at all after reading everyone's input.  I'm scared to death.  Should I not be worried about metastasis because I'm stage II?  I think you all have some messed up information and talking about it with your Dr IS the best thing to do.  Hope you all have a great day :)
Posts.Title: suggestion when confronted with confusing path reports fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 03:59PM anji111 wrote: I thank God for you too.  My sister had CUP (they said it was glandular first, then lung then CUP) and was diagnosed in Sept 00.  Even though they had found a spot on her lung x-ray in April that year.  They did absolutely nothing for her.  I can't understand that.  By the time she went to the doctor in September, after being sick all summer, she was stage iv and had fluid in the lining of her lung.  The 'nice' doctor gave her six months and she lasted ten.  By that time it was everywhere.  I now have BC.  So when I was diagnosed it was like a death sentence.  I saw my Doctor yesterday and he said I should do great and be positive.  I'm trying.  I go for bone scan, chest x-ray and ultrasound on the 17th.  (I had a right mastectomy on March 18th and still healing).  My sister was only 41, no kids.  I hope that wasn't the reason they did nothing.  Actually, she had terrible care the whole time.  She knew something was wrong and was told by some doctors to just get out of their office it was all in her head.  She was feeling really sick once too and the 'nurse' told her to just eat some crackers.  It wasn't a hangover!  Anyway, I absolutely agree that finding things out early can help (if they will treat you).  Maybe my sister would still be here.  Best wishes to all you.  Thanks for being here.
Posts.Title: Early Detection of Mets- Does it Matter? TripleNeg RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2009 10:14AM anji111 wrote: Hi, my name is Anji.  I, hopefully, (I can't believe I just said that) am starting Chemo in May.  I have my first appointment with an oncologist on May 6th.  I have a Muga scan that day too.  I found a lump in January, had a biopsy in February and right Mastectomy in March.  I looked for a May 2009 group and couldn't find one.  Can anyone help? Thank you.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2009 12:04PM anji111 wrote: Thank you all so much for responding.  Just reading through this website the last few weeks has been so helpful.  I hate to admit it but I really think I'm going to need the support when I'm going through it.  A lot of my 'best friends' are really not here for me at all.  I don't understand why and am too scared to ask.  Seems silly.  I'm starting to cry now so I think I'll stop.  Thanks again everyone, and I hope you all continue to do well.  It's nice seeing pictures of you.  Putting a face to a name.  I'm illiterate in that dept :) maybe I can get one of my kids to help me....
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012
